Summary: The proposal introduces AdaCurv, an adaptive optimizer that leverages curvature-aware updates and gradient coherence filtering to improve convergence and generalization in non-convex optimization landscapes. The method combines low-rank Hessian approximation, gradient coherence scores, and memory-efficient Kronecker-factored updates. The experiment plan includes synthetic benchmarks, deep learning tasks, language model pretraining, theoretical analysis, and hardware efficiency benchmarks.
Strengths: Innovative integration of curvature-awareness and gradient coherence filtering.
Comprehensive experiment plan covering multiple aspects of evaluation.
Strong theoretical foundation with proposed convergence guarantees.
Weaknesses: Lacks detailed discussion on computational overhead of curvature estimation.
Unclear robustness of gradient coherence filtering in highly noisy environments.
Execution plan could benefit from more concrete risk mitigation strategies.
Scalability to very large models is not fully demonstrated.
Questions: How will the computational overhead of curvature estimation be managed in large-scale models?
What are the failure modes of gradient coherence filtering, and how will they be addressed?
Can the proposed method scale to billion-parameter models without significant memory or time penalties?
What are the specific assumptions underlying the convergence guarantees, and how do they compare to prior work?
Limitations: Potential high computational cost due to curvature estimation.
Gradient coherence filtering may not perform well in extremely noisy environments.
Scalability to very large models is not fully demonstrated.
Theoretical guarantees may be limited by the complexity of non-convex landscapes.
